subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] learning
msgSnippet: Welcome to the Read group! I m glad to hear that a 10 year old is interested in the Alphabet. Keep us abreast of his progress. You will find that this group -
messageBody:
Re: [Read_Alphabet] learning
Welcome to the Read group! I'm glad to hear that a 10 year old is interested in the Alphabet. Keep us abreast of his progress.

You will find that this group - unlike the Shavians -  is not too hung up on the fine points of spelling.   It's just about communication, and you will know quickly if you are communicating.

While I'm not from New York, I have lived there for 25 years, and recognize that, while there a great number of accents, for the most part they  are close to "Middle Atlantic" speech and will look the same in Read. It's not that you are from Louisiana or something.

You might also want to make some flash cards with Read words to work with your son.  And try keeping your shopping list in Read!





Hi all,

I discovered this site and the Read Alphabet a few weeks ago. I
decided to learn it. I really love it. Even my 10-year-old son has
started to learn it.

Do you have any suggestions on how to learn and practice this
wonderful writting system?

I pretty much can grasp all the sounds, but I have a little problem
with the "ah" in "alms" & "ox" sounds. I pronounce them pretty much
the same. I'm from New York, I wonder if that makes a difference? Is
it acceptable to interchange them in my case, as I do not
differentiate between them?

Thanks,
Chris
